THE PLACE

The Observatory, Port Macquarie.

THE LOCATION

Directly opposite the town's most popular beach where iconic Norfolk pines line the shore, the mult

winning 4.5-star Observatory, one of only three carbon neutral hotels in Australia, looks across parkland, golden sand and rolling surf. It's a couple of minutes' stroll to Town beach, where you can join the nine-kilome

coastal walkway, while the township is a short distance away. Port Macquarie is a four-hour drive north of Sydney and is a popular holiday destination and retirement hotspot.

THE SPACE

At first glance, The Observatory

s no different to any other modern strata apartment hotel. The difference is the warm and friendly staff who go the extra mile for guests, while a wall-mounted monitor at reception provides an up- to-date picture of the

energy savings - giving the first clue to the hotel's phenomenal carbon-neutral status. More than 200 solar panels on the hotel's rooftop generate enough electricity to support the energy usage of 100 hotel guests weekl

(more than 5000 annually). Guests can recharge electric vehicles free of charge in the car park, a 22-kilolitre rainwater tank refills the pool and spa, while energy efficient lighting and appliances are par for the cou

The hotel, named Australasia's Best Sustainable Boutique Hotel (2014 World Boutique Hotel Awards), is also mindful of local history. During construction, convict-era relics such as china and coins were unearthed and the

are now displayed in the entry halls.

THE ROOM

The Observatory offers boutique beachfront accommodation with 34 hotel rooms and 57 ocean view apartments, including two penthouses. For an additional $50 per stay, the O

package has fair trade tea and coffee, Wii Fit DVDs and exercise equipment, a welcome platter, green bathroom products and a library of DVDs and books. A free beach ball and use of adult and kids' bikes is thrown in. Th

package helps fund sustainability initiatives; including native bush regeneration, tree planting, and the rehabilitation of sick and injured animals at the nearby Koala Hospital.

We stay in the swanky house-sized Penth

apartment with views up the coastline to Point Plomer from the ballroom-sized balcony accessible though bifold glass doors. The penthouses are ideal for large families or friends 

travelling together, with three bedroo

and two bathrooms stocked with eco-friendly amenities. The decor is contemporary and the apartment is light-filled and comfortable, with every conceivable mod con.

THE FOOD

The Observatory's apartments have full kitch

while on-site are seafood restaurant Scampis and Milkbar, which is a popular beachside cafe with decent coffee, house-made icy poles and terrific breakfasts. A stroll up the road will bring you to the Stunned Mullet, th

region's only hatted restaurant, perfect for long lazy lunches overlooking the sea. Hip local hangout, Social Grounds, on the way in or out of Port Macquarie, offers arguably Port's best coffee, with creative cafe-style

.

STEPPING OUT

Borrow one of The Observatory's iPods and take an audio-visual self-guided tour to the picturesque Tacking Point Lighthouse, and be sure to spend time at one of Port Macquarie's eight gorgeous beaches. B

Zoo is a fun day out, offering a fabulous snow leopard encounter and new cheetah exhibition featuring Warrior and Vongani recently arrived from South Africa. Award-winning Ricardoes Tomatoes and Strawberries (15 minutes

drive away) does hands-down the best Devonshire tea on the coast, with scones handmade by a local woman and jam produced from the hydroponic farm's lush pick-your-own strawberries.

THE VERDICT

If a hotel stay is all a

location, you can't beat the Observatory's plum beachfront position, while its impressive green credentials make you feel extra-virtuous about your stay.

ESSENTIALS

40 William Street, Port Macquarie. Rooms start from

a night. Two night stays receive a "Savour the Flavour" pack including two bottles of local wine, cheese, chutney and lavash, handmade chocolates and a four-pack of Black Duck Beer until December 24. Phone (02) 6586 800

0, see observatory.net.au.

HIGHLIGHT

Watching sunrise over Town Beach from the rooftop terrace.

LOWLIGHT

No room service, however some local restaurants will deliver.

Sheriden Rhodes was a guest of

CITY, Mont. — Robert B. Price, the chief executive of a London-based oil and gas company, came up with a creative tactic to grab bargain drilling rights to a sprawling piece of federal land here in eastern Montana — eac

acre for less than the price of a cup of coffee.

He first asked the Interior Department to auction off rights to as much as 200,000 acres in Montana through a process that allows energy companies to identify the public

d they would like to develop. But when the auction took place last December, Mr. Price sat on the sidelines and waited for the clock to run out — betting no one else would bid.

His gamble worked. With no other bidders s

interest, the government allowed him to secure drilling rights on nearly 67,000 acres east of Miles City in a special noncompetitive sale the very next day. His cost: just $1.50 an acre a year in rent, compared with the

e than $100-an-acre average paid by bidders, on top of rent, in competitive auctions in Montana in the final four years of the Obama administration.

“We’re still interested in much more,” said Mr. Price, reached by phon

before he was scheduled to fly to London to meet with his investors.

The maneuver is one of many loopholes that energy speculators like Mr. Price are using as the Trump administration undertakes a burst of lease sales

federal lands in the West.

Major oil and gas companies like Chevron and Chesapeake Energy are frequent buyers of the leases. But the Trump administration has put so much land up for lease that it has also created an op

for super-low-price buyers like Mr. Price.

The plots of land the speculators bid on typically sell for such dirt-cheap prices because there is little evidence that much oil or gas is easily accessible. The buyers are h

that the land will increase in value nonetheless, because of higher energy prices, new technologies that could make exploration and drilling more economical or the emergence of markets for other resources hidden beneath

e surface.

In some cases they hope to resell access to deep-pocketed oil companies at a premium. In others they are hoping to raise money to search for oil or gas on their own. Either way, they are the latest in a long

of speculators willing to take a shot — sometimes a very long shot — at a big payoff in America’s oil fields. 

The percentage of leases being given away through noncompetitive sales, like the one that Mr. Price enginee

surged in the first year of the Trump administration to the highest levels in over a decade, according to an analysis of federal leasing data by Taxpayers for Common Sense, a nonpartisan group that highlights what it co

wasteful actions by federal government agencies.

In states like Nevada, noncompetitive sales frequently make up a majority of leases given out by the federal government, the group’s database shows.

The growth of the a

of land put up for lease combined with the sharp increase in noncompetitive leasing has resulted in major drops in the price companies pay per acre in certain states, like Montana, where the average bid has fallen by 80

t compared with the final years of the Obama administration.

Two Grand Junction, Colo., business partners, for example — a geologist and a former Gulf Oil landman — now control 276,653 acres of federal parcels in northe

Nevada. But they are still looking for the money they need to drill on the land, or even to pay for three-dimensional seismic surveys to determine whether there is enough oil there to try.

In the case of Mr. Price, who

investors include Haliburton, the oil-services industry giant, he is convinced that there is an unusually high level of helium mixed in with natural gas that could be drilled in eastern Montana. Because helium sells at

much higher price than even oil, he is selling investors on the potential for lucrative returns. But the prospect of him delivering remains in doubt.

Rajan David Ahuja, vice president at R&R Royalty, a Texas-based comp

that has leases on land roughly equivalent to the size of Rhode Island, said that building landholdings like this was a crapshoot.

“We don’t make money on 90 percent of the things we do,” Mr. Ahuja said. “It is a reall

risky game.”

The surge in noncompetitive transactions has intensified debate over how well the federal government handles the task of auctioning off access to taxpayer-owned lands. Taxpayers get 12.5 percent of revenue

produced from any oil or gas extracted from leased public land — or nothing but trivial rent payments if speculators fail to develop the land successfully.

More than 11 million acres of land leased by the federal gover

lies idle — or about half of all the land out on lease — property that may or may not ever be drilled for oil and gas.

The speculation, critics say, allows companies to lock up millions of acres of federal land in leas

complicating efforts to set it aside for other uses, such as wildlife conservation areas or hunting and recreation zones.

“People come to Montana and stay in Montana not because of the best weather or highest wages or

best beaches,” said John Todd, the conservation director at the Montana Wilderness Association. “They come here because we have access to ample public land, most of it that is in the same shape as it was when Lewis and

came here or before that.”

Because the speculators can resell the leases, they could also reap the gains from any increase in the value of their landholdings, gains that otherwise would go to American taxpayers, said R

Alexander, president of Taxpayers for Common Sense.

“We should not be flooding the market so it is easy for companies to sit back and wait to get to leases at fire-sale prices,” Ms. Alexander said. “The acceleration of

g is doing just that. The industry is getting a great deal and taxpayers are not.”

Ryan Zinke, the interior secretary, said this month that overall taxpayer revenue from energy production on federal lands jumped in 2018

s a result of rising production in states like Wyoming and New Mexico.

“President Trump’s energy dominance strategy is paying off, and local communities across America are the beneficiaries,” Mr. Zinke said in a stateme

The Speculators’ Walmart

Inside the George R. Brown Convention Center in downtown Houston, thousands of energy industry executives converged in August for an event known as Summer NAPE, a giant gathering of hundreds

owners of potential oil and gas drilling sites. Most of them were there to raise money to turn their speculative gambles into real drilling plans.

“STRIKE WHILE THE DEALS ARE HOT,” the banner at the entrance to the mee

hall said.

At Booth 2315, in front of a poster boasting about the more than 261,000 acres of federal leases they had secured in Nevada, stood Larry R. Moyer, a Colorado-based oil geologist, and his business partner, St

Smith, a former Gulf Oil landman, pitching their land to any prospective investor who walked up.

“You want to get in our deal — get your checkbook out,” Mr. Smith said to one visitor.

Northern Nevada, Mr. Smith admits

, is a risky place to look for oil. Nevada has one of the highest percentages in the country of leased land that is sitting idle: Just 3 percent of the 715,441 acres of federal land in the state leased for oil and gas we

actually producing energy as of late last year.

“There are a lot of people who have spent a lot of money drilling dry holes in the past,” Mr. Smith said.

“We are working to overcome the conventional wisdom,” Mr. Moyer

.

Mr. Moyer took to a small stage at the Houston conference for a “Shark Tank”-like presentation.

“What we are looking for — or we would ask someone — is about $10 million,” Mr. Moyer said, money they would use for a s

survey and to drill test wells.

“If you find a billion barrels, your finding cost is going to be a penny a barrel,” he said before wrapping up his presentation by saying, “Think about taking a swing.”

Waiting on the S

The bidding process typically begins when an oil and gas company asks the Interior Department to open up a new chunk of taxpayer-owned land to drilling.

Once the department agrees, it schedules an internet-based aucti

for registered bidders. Hot competition for the most sought-after land, where there are proven energy reserves, can drive these so-called bonus bids up close to $100,000 per acre, as happened in New Mexico in September.

t to ensure that there is at least some upfront payment, the Interior Department requires a minimum per-acre bid of $2.

But there is a loophole. If no one bids, the land is then transferred into a program that allows an

to approach the department within two years of the auction, without an upfront bid payment.

The only money that needs to be put down is the $1.50-per-acre annual lease payment for the first year of a 10- year lease, an

a $75 filing fee. This is how Mr. Price managed to secure access to land in Custer County, east of Miles City, part of the 116,000 acres of federal leases his company, Highlands Montana, says it holds.

“We’re a small c

We didn’t want to get in a bidding process,” said Mr. Price, whose company has raised at least $6 million from investors since 2016.

Mr. Moyer and Mr. Smith also secured a large share of their holdings in Nevada throug

these noncompetitive purchases, after sitting and watching the auctions play out without bidding.

But Neil Kornze, the former head of the Bureau of Land Management, the branch of the Interior Department that runs the l

process, said this was a flawed policy. 

“Someone should have to bid in the auction to get the land,” said Mr. Kornze, who served as director in the final three years of the Obama administration.

The Trump administrat

made three times as much land available to bid on in the last fiscal year as the average for the last four years of the Obama administration. But only about 11 percent of the land attracted any bidders in 2018 — a total

f 1.35 million acres. The rest of that land is now available for noncompetitive leases.

Highlands Montana has drilled a few test wells on adjacent state land it has leased here. But for now, most of Mr. Price’s leased l

remains undeveloped.

Large-scale development would be quite a shock in this part of Montana, where there is now very little oil and gas drilling.

From the back porch of the cattle ranch owned by Karen Aspevig Stevenso

and her husband, the view stretches for miles, with ponderosa pines and juniper bushes swaying in a wind that blows so strong it sounds almost like ocean waves.

“This is our public lands. We all own this land,” Ms. Ste

said, as she walked through the rolling hills, her cattle-herding dog running ahead. “To come in here and just start drilling — that does not make sense.”

Eric Lipton reported from Miles City and Houston, and Hiroko Ta

buchi from New York. Rachel Shorey contributed research.

year 1913 was a good one for American bison -- one of the first good years for bison since the early 19th century. In February, the new buffalo nickel was introduced. And on Nov. 25, two railroad express cars loaded wit

14 bison left the New York Zoological Park, now called the Bronx Zoo, for the town of Hot Springs in the Black Hills of South Dakota. On the 28th, the bison were taken overland in their crates 11 more miles and released

o native grassland.

Those bison were a gift to the federal government from the American Bison Society and the New York Zoological Society. Their descendants, still living in what is now Wind Cave National Park, are amon

the only pure American bison left, untainted by the DNA of cattle, which are often crossbred with bison for their meat. That shipment of animals, from private ownership to public land, was a landmark in wildlife conserv

By one reliable estimate, there were only 635 wild, free-running bison left in North America in 1889 -- 550 of them in Canada. In the early 1870s, Congress had tried and failed to pass legislation protecting the animal

while white hunters were killing them by the millions; more than three million were slaughtered between 1872 and 1874. Untold masses of hides were shipped to the East in what may be the most profligate ecocide in human

And in return, out of the East, came those 14 bison.

The innumerable herds and the ecosystem that sustained them were gone, and with them any firm scientific understanding of the behavior and effect of those incredible

numbers. But if the herds were gone, at least the species would survive, protected in its natural habitat. It would have been wonderful to have had a glimpse of the plains blackened with moving bison. It was surely stirring -- hopeful and saddening at the same time -- to see those 14 New York City bison sniffing the unfamiliar air of South Dakota.

sport of fishing may be about to experience its biggest revolution in nearly 90 years thanks to an app developed by Swedish start-up FishBrain.

Relying on the average piscator's impulse to brag about a catch, FishBrain

s shared photos of fish to generate big data. The company says it has logged enough data to predict when and where fish will bite.

Recreational fishing is one of the world's most practised hobbies and a number of apps h

hit the market in recent years as technology improves.

"Building a bigger user base is the key focus for 2015," FishBrain's chief executive Johan Attby, 40, said from Stockholm. "The goal is to become the first-choice

for anglers worldwide."

The social network is introducing an algorithm to forecast when and where to drop a line for a particular species, based on the 225,000 catches users have logged. The big-data version of the app

e available on Android last week and on iOS this week.

But the company could be in for a challenge if it wants to snag Victorian users.

Fly-fishing veteran Alistair Purvey said nothing can beat experience. "It doesn't

all the time, but you just acquire knowledge," he said.

The younger generation of fishers are also sceptical. Mathew Anderson, 24, from Compleat Angler Melbourne said tips were already shared on online forums.

Though

uses phone apps for other purposes, he doubted a fishing app could be kept up-to-date and attract experienced fishers willing to disclose their secrets.

"If someone published a certain location there could be a thousan

people in one spot," Mr Anderson said.

He said previous fishing apps had fallen flat.

Niche social networks are attracting investor appetite. Strava, an online community for running and cycling, in October raised A$22

n from investors including Sequoia Capital. Attby, who is more into bikes than fish, said his idea was to find a community with many potential users.

Combining a specialised social network with big data, Attby hopes to

the solunar theory - a method proposed in 1926 that is still popular today - in predicting when fish will strike. 

FishBrain's app gathers a range of automatic data including wind speed and water temperature while user

log information about their catch and the equipment used to land it. Algorithms then predict where to find nine species including northern pike, largemouth bass and spotted seatrout.

The company, which was founded in 2

011 and introduced its app last year, now has 650,000 users. More than two- thirds are in the US, where it dominates the market.

The company employs 12 people, a number Attby predicts will grow to about 100 in a year or two.

The vigilance team probing the role of chief minister Oommen Chandy's former gunman Salim Raj and his relatives in the alleged land grabbing at Kadakampally has submitted an interim probe report before the high court on

.

The report was filed by vigilance DSP Rajendran in a sealed cover to the court. On October 25, the court had expressed its displeasure over the delay by the vigilance team and had asked them to explain what all they h

investigated so far in the probe that began in July.

While directing the vigilance and anti corruption bureau to complete the probe within two months, the court clarified that the vigilance report would be helpful for

CBI inquiry later on.

The directives were issued by the court while considering a petition filed by Premchand R Nair and others of Thiruvananthapuram alleging that Salim Raj's relatives with his aid deprived them of ov

45 acres of land at Kadakampally in Thiruvananthapuram.

Salim Raj's relative Abdul Majeed and one Jayaram had entered into an agreement to purchase four acres of the 45-acre of land at Rs 50,000/cent. It is alleged tha

false 'thandaper' was created in revenue records with the help of Salim Raj.

The government had sought six more months to complete the probe; however, the court declined the demand stating that such a long period was n

necessary.

It was also ordered that the vigilance should submit a copy of the final report on the investigation to the high court as soon as the probe was over.

Last week, while considering a solar scam case, the cour

t had said the way Salim Raj was questioned by the vigilance team in the Kadakampally case was a mockery. Theoretically, the government was doing everything but practically, it was doing nothing, the court had said.

new coal-fired, electricity-generating plants discussed in the Nov. 24 front-page article "Boom in electric cars boosts demand for coal power" were contracted for construction before electric vehicles seriously entered

marketplace. These plants, combined, have 3,516 megawatts of generating capacity. The total Dutch electric car electricity demand is about 50 megawatts. Electric vehicles neither drove the installation of these coal-fir

plants nor represent a meaningful share of the plants' electricity production.

Also, the increasing generation of renewable energy in the Netherlands is far greater than the increased electricity demand created by elec

vehicles on Dutch roads. It is a truism that the electric car is only as clean as its electricity supply. Fully powered by coal electricity, an electric vehicle is about the equivalent of a 35 mpg car. Fully powered by

or the sun, its equivalent is well above 100 mpg.

Around the world, electricity generation is getting cleaner with each passing year for reasons that include more efficient fossil fuel power plants (coal and gas), extr

fast renewable energy growth and better system management. Thus, whether in the Netherlands or in the D.C. suburbs, an electric car is a relatively low-polluting vehicle today and will be even less polluting tomorrow.

m Siegel , McLean

l

Electric cars are indeed a good thing. The real problem is that coal and fracked natural gas are so cheap that renewable energy has not completely driven these energy sources out of the marketplace,

e these commodities do not have to pay the cost of the environmental damage that they inflict.

The obvious solution would be to follow the World Bank's recommendation of enacting "carbon fee" legislation so that these f

fuels would be charged steadily rising fees that would be returned to consumers. This measure would not grow government but would help the Netherlands and many parts of the United States to stop relying on cheap U.S. co

al at the great cost of sea-level rise, ocean acidification and heat-driven crop failures.

We cannot expect to shift to renewable energy in a timely fashion without using the marketplace, because when money talks, nobody walks. 

Chris Wiegard , Chester, Va.

unsung inventors

The individual inventor has been a powerful force in the creation of many inventions and technologies which have contributed hugely to our economic prosperity. The government's innovation statement is

in that it offers no support to them.

Over the past 20 years, individual inventors have been abandoned by: IP Australia (it administers the intellectual property rights system) which closed its state offices; the court

in that costs relating to infringement cases are extreme and settlements insignificant; and the government, in that you must be a registered company with substantial turnover to be eligible for assistance.

I have been

the committee of the Inventors Association for 35 years, assisting hundreds of people to commercialise their ideas. Without government support, many have run out of money and their ideas and patents have been lost. If w

are to become an innovative nation, initiatives supporting inventors must be created in areas of patents, prototyping, production and commercialisation.

Frank Bishop, Croydon North

Cruelty-free coffees

A small-scale

(The Age, 15/2) is welcome news after endless stories about huge mega-dairies and the attendant cow welfare problems that factory farming imposes. However, even to produce "craft" milk for cafes' lattes, hundreds of cal

the rightful recipients of their mothers' milk, are sacrificed in abattoirs when they are only five days old. Choosing a soy latte instead is a cruelty-free option.

Jan Kendall, Hawthorn

Nothing but the best

So Forei

Minister Julie Bishop spent more than $1700 of taxpayers' money on three beanbags as part of the federal government's innovationXchange initiative. They were Armani beanbags, of course.Meredith Andrews,

Seacliff, SA

hearts and minds

Judy Courtin's excoriating critique of the performance of Catholic bishops before the royal commission is spot on in every respect but one: these men are not "the Catholic Church". They temporarily hol

senior administrative positions but our church exists primarily in the hearts and minds of its members. 

It is true that they have failed us badly and they obstinately continue not to see that. Thankfully they will eve

pass on and we will begin to recover from the shame.

The best historical footnote they can now hope for is in Shakespeare's Julius Caesar: "The evil that men do lives after them, the good is oft interred with their bon

Peter Sheehan, Camberwell

Benefit of the doubt

I am far from being a fan of George Pell, but I hate unfairness. Have those who are critical of his "no show" at the royal commission got proof that he is not ill? Cardi

Pell was never one to back away from a fight.

Frank O'Dea, Box Hill

True to our church

I cannot commend too highly Mary Dalmau's letter (14/12). It is vitally important for us Catholics to make clear that, no matter

disgusted we may be at our betrayal by the (Rome-appointed) bishops, we will not abandon Christ's church, nor will we be muzzled.

Fred Bendeich, Camberwell

Rise and fall of gods

I was comfortable with Mary Dalmau's c

of the Catholic Church as a man-made organisation about power, money and control. I was with her right up until her last comment, "yet I refuse to allow them to take my faith from me". Why not man-made church, man-made

The history of our species encompasses the worship of thousands of gods who rose and fell with the rise and fall of the cultures that created them. To summarise H. L. Mencken: They were gods of the highest dignity - god

of civilised peoples - worshipped and believed in by millions. All were omnipotent, omniscient and immortal. And all are dead.

Alan Cooper, Ashburton

Where's our box gone?

Concerns about high postage costs (Letters,

no longer bother those of us in South Eltham.

Our only post box was summarily removed in April with none of the public consultation process so clearly outlined on Australia Post's website. A meeting with representative

called to reassure the public has had no effect. Is this the way the corporatised public service is supposed to be? How will they make a profit with no customers?

Rex Niven, Eltham

Cheat-proof stamps

Don't ask me how

I know this, but Australia Post chief Ahmed Fahour may be interested to learn that British stamps that come through the system unfranked cannot be soaked off for re-use. He would do well to adopt this technology here and

s avoid losing valuable revenue.

Elaine O'Shannessy,

Wandin North

Eliminate concessions 

If the budget has a serious deficit problem (The Age, 15/112), surely the first action on tax reform has to be the removal of t

concessions that are generous or counterproductive. In particular the concessions on negative gearing, capital gains, superannuation and fossil fuel subsidies. Clearly, we cannot afford them any more.

Richard Fone, Cam

Not another selfie

Goodness knows we have more than enough rules to keep the police busy, but I do wish there was a selfie ban in Federation Square when there is entertainment on. The last thing I want to see is badly

d tourists taking photos of themselves, blocking out a joyful choir giving its all for Australia at Christmas.

Mish Stephenson, Melbourne

Matter of sustainability

When the chest beating and high words subside, unless

impact of the increasing world population is part of the discussion, the agreed aims of the Paris climate summit will not be possible. Profit-driven economic growth requiring rampant consumerism, land clearing and burni

addiction to the use of motorised vehicles and continued reliance on coal mining for energy will inevitably produce increasing emissions from a growing world population. More sustainable solutions are required.

Gloria

Pakenham Upper

Banishing the drys

John Howard was able to rid his parliamentary party of those whom he described as "wets". It appears the current condition of tenure for the job of prime minister will prevent Malcol

Turnbull from doing the same to the "drys". So the gaggle of right-wing dinosaurs and climate change deniers hold sway. The frustration for Mr Turnbull must be palpable.

Neil McDonald, Berwick

Tolls not the only way

will be predictable outrage from motorists if road tolls are extended (The Age, 14/12). Perhaps this is not the only way to free up congested roads. More than 90 per cent of traffic are driver-only vehicles. They are pa

of the problem, so another solution may be useful. Discouraging single-person vehicles, encouraging car sharing or, best of all, improving public transport would be preferable. However, I cannot see this happening.

Ian

, Hawthorn

Against the odds

Australian cricket commentators and fans are critical of the West Indies for their poor performance in the Test match. What is not mentioned is that the team is drawn from mainly small islan

nations with a total population of a few million. Playing against Australia's well-organised squad from the six Shield teams, drawn from a population base of nearly 24 million, it is a wonder the Windies have done so we

in the past.

Leo Gamble, Mentone

Please, not the horn

I have lived near a train station for many years. I get a maximum of five hours uninterrupted sleep (the period between the last and first trains) due to the rela

recent practice of trains tooting their horns. Metro Trains told

to be expected in today's legal climate," said Gregg Overman, director of communications for the Allied Pilots Association, the union that represents American Airlines pilots. "I wouldn't want to characterize it as all

g — and China and the United States are racing to create a future that aligns with their own distinct visions. The result could be an overhaul of 20th-century trade rules for a 21st-century global economic order, in whic

g use of “smart factories” doing sophisticated work with fewer people. And the deal that woke up the world to China’s plan was a German one.

animals it was introduced in the early 20th century to supplement a struggling mainland population. Kangaroo Island in this sense functioned as a kind of ark, while its own native species evolved subtle distinctions fro

their mainland cousins.

Flinders Chase was devastated by an uncontrolled bushfire in 2007 but has regenerated well. The island has no rabbits or foxes and, combined with its rich and varied soil types plus the fact much of this area has never

farmed, it makes this remote corner a hotbed of biodiversity.

I meet up with a hiker from Darwin named Chris, and his teenage son, Ira. Chris tells me they always take their holidays in cool places, to escape the oppre

heat of the north. As if on cue a mean wind whips the trees into a demented sway, a sudden sun-shower wets the petals of the wildflowers, and we stride out a bit faster towards our first night campsite at Snake Lagoon.

r campsites have been specially constructed for the trail, although self-guided hiking and camping is just one option. You can choose a guided tour, camping with your guide at the sites, or stay in off-park accommodation

h night, with transfers back to the trail in the morning. The campsites feature impressive landscape architecture, with 24 tent platforms constructed in the bush, minimising environmental impact. Each site has its own co

dirt path, and at busy times the campgrounds hum with atmosphere as hikers gather in the solar-powered communal kitchen and dining areas to share trail stories. But I'm happy to dine alone under the sugar gums, amid the

n 

whistlers, New Holland honeyeaters, shy heath wrens, grey fantails and the beautiful scarlet robins with orange breasts that flicker like torches as they dart between the branches.

y the trail bends inland and into the sheltered haven of Hakea Campsite.

p it shut in case of snakes.

carbon dioxide emissions are projected to rise again in 2017, climate scientists reported Monday, a troubling development for the environment and a major disappointment for those who had hoped emissions of the climate c

gas had at last peaked.

The emissions from fossil fuel burning and industrial uses are projected to rise by up to 2 percent in 2017, as well as to rise again in 2018, the scientists told a group of international offici

gathered for a United Nations climate conference in Bonn, Germany.

Despite global economic growth, total emissions held level from 2014 to 2016 at about 36 billion tons per year, stoking hope among many climate-change

that emissions had reached an all-time high point and would begin to decline. But that was not to be, the new analysis suggests.

"The temporary hiatus appears to have ended in 2017," wrote Stanford University's Rob Jac

who along with colleagues at the Global Carbon Project tracked 2017 emissions to date and projected them forward. "Economic projections suggest further emissions growth in 2018 is likely."

The renewed rise is a troubli

development for the global effort to keep atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases below the levels needed to mitigate the worst effects of climate change. The more we emit now, scientists say, the more severe cut

will have to be later. That's because of the very long atmospheric lifetime of carbon dioxide, which means we can only emit a fixed amount in total if we want to stay within key climate goals.

"It's sort of, lose one y

now, you have to pick up five years later," said Glen Peters, one of the study's co-authors and a researcher at the Center for International Climate Research in Oslo.

Emissions are forecast to reach around 37 billion t

of carbon dioxide from fossil fuel burning and industrial activity in 2017, said the group, which published the results in the journal Environmental Research Letters and more detailed findings in Earth System Science Da

Discussions. The renewed increase is driven largely by more fossil fuel burning in China and many other nations. 

"We've been lucky in the last three years with emissions being flat without any real policy driving it,"

s said. "If we want to ensure that emissions remain flat we have to put policies in place . . . and the second step is to start to drive emissions down."

Peters said the 2017 number would be a record high for emissions

fossil fuel burning and industrial uses (such as cement), although carbon emissions from deforestation and land-use changes were higher in 2015.

The scientists also acknowledge some uncertainty in their estimate, meani

that the 2017 emissions rise could be as low as 1 percent or as high as 3 percent.

All in all, the finding is bad news for global climate policy. The Paris agreement, now supported by every nation except for the United

, aims to limit the warming of the planet to "well below" 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) above preindustrial levels, and to try to hold warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit).

But this requi

emissions not just to stay flat but to go down - rapidly.

"The 2017 emissions data make it crystal clear that urgent and very serious emissions reductions are needed to stop global warming below 2 degrees C, as was una

agreed in Paris," Stefan Rahmstorf, a climate scientist at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research in Germany, said in an email. Rahmstorf was not involved with the current work.

Rahmstorf said there are abou

600 billion remaining tons of carbon dioxide that can be emitted if the world is to have a good chance of keeping warming considerably below 2 degrees Celsius, and with about 40 billion tons of emissions each year, that

s 15 years.

"If we start to ramp down emissions from now on we can stretch this budget to last us about 30 years," he said. "With every year that we wait we will have to stop using fossil energy even earlier."

The rise

f global emissions projected for 2017 in the current research is attributable to multiple causes.

In particular, China's emissions were projected to increase by 3.5 percent in 2017 as the country consumed more of all th

of the top fossil fuels - coal, natural gas and oil. China is the single largest emitting country.

India, which has been experiencing rapid emissions growth, will pull back to 2 percent growth in 2017 because of econom

contraction, the research suggests.

 Emissions from the United States and European Union are projected to decline 0.4 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively. But emissions for the rest of the globe - which, in total, ar

even larger than China's - will rise by close to 2 percent, according to the projection.

If the increase continues, what many hoped was a plateau in emissions seen from 2014 to 2016 could come to look more like a pause

During that era, many cited a broad "decoupling" of economic growth and emissions growth, thanks in part to greater energy efficiency and renewable energy. And renewables are continuing to grow around the world - makin

it hard to know quite what to make of the current emissions rise.

"It's too early to say whether it's a long-term trend, or just a one-off little blip," Peters said.

While 37 billion tons of carbon dioxide from fossil

s and industry represent the lion's share of the globe's emissions, there are also several billion tons of carbon dioxide each year from deforestation and other changes in how people use land. When it comes to global tre

e loss, there are also worrying signs that it is not abating as hoped. 

There are also rising emissions of methane, a greenhouse gas that is a stronger and faster warming agent, although not nearly as long-lived in the atmosphere as carbon dioxide. There is still a debate over where the methane growth is coming from, but much of it could be from animal agriculture.

threat to Soweto I first met Israel Mosala in a small greenhouse tucked away in a corner of Joubert Park in Johannesburg's notorious Hillbrow district. I'd scheduled a meeting with EarthLife Africa, a non-profit organis

driven by a small but dedicated group of volunteers and one of the first to voice concern about acid mine drainage (AMD).

 The case of Davidsonville

 Mosala was late. He shuffled in apologetically and took a seat with

meeting my eyes. His body was thin and energetic and he was dressed in tight-fitting jeans and a tucked-in T-shirt. I asked him where he was from. "Meadowlands. Soweto," he quietly replied, his head still bowed. As we d

there together, Mosala told me that it was the constant presence of mine waste in his home area that spurred him into action and thrust him into his work -- leading educational activities supported by EarthLife. Soweto

host to several large mine dumps and the Klip River, which snakes through the suburb, polluted by sewage, garbage and mine waste. On windy days parts of the area are shrouded in mine dust and become nearly invisible. Po

of acid water from Gauteng's Western Basin -- where it has been accumulating in empty mine shafts, reaching the surface and polluting waterways since 2002 -- lie beside the busy Elias Motsoaledi highway, a stone's throw

m the densely populated Braamfischerville and the new RDP development, Sol Plaatje. According to a test done for the Mail & Guardian, the water has a pH, a measure of acidity, of 2. Safe water, or what scientists call ne

water, has a pH of 7. Concerns that Africa's biggest city could be seriously affected by AMD have turned attention away from the fact that the area that houses two-thirds of Johannesburg's population is already living w

acid water. Holy water To visit the Klip River at a weekend is to visit a pulsing, teeming church. Before even seeing the river, passersby can hear drums and singing. Throngs of worshippers line the water. They are in d

positions and states of meditation. The atmosphere is calm and serene, with libations and prayers taking place from sunrise to sundown. Men and women of all denominations show up on foot or packed into cars, with family

friends, or individually, to pray and have their souls cleansed by the Klip's cold, forgiving water. Simpiwe, a young sangoma who will not give his surname, said the water can help with many ailments. "We believe that w

cleans everything ... If there is cancer, you've got bad luck, spirits are hurting you, then you come here to cleanse ... There are spirits which are flowing here." The Klip embodies more than just the substance that it

. "When a person is born, they are inside the water," said Simpiwe. "Water is very important because it protects you from the tummy of your mom. The nurse used ... water to wash you. When Jesus was baptised, he went to t

River Jordan and John baptised him there. We are using the water to wash ourselves, our clothes, even looking after the plants. Water is very important." But the Klip River is 

dying. DRD Gold's Crown Operation Besides

e seepage from the dumps that surround Soweto, residents and environmental activists said that the river is also potentially threatened by DRD Gold's Crown Operation, which is upstream, and a new Central Rand Gold operat

housed upstream from the New Canada Dam. A test of water from a leaking pipe coming from the operation, which is next to a wetland, showed a pH of 2. But both companies maintain the river is not being affected by their

DRD Gold said an investigation was undertaken which found that no irregular spillage is taking place at the site. In an email from Central Rand Gold, the company said: "[Our] operation is based approximately 5km away fr

the New Canada Dam ... We run a closed circuit and don't discharge any water outside of our mining area." An analysis conducted by Waterlab, an independent water-testing company, on behalf of the M&G, showed the Klip ha

a pH of 4,9, with elevated levels of iron and manganese, both by-products of AMD. According to Louis de Wet of Waterlab, who conducted the tests, these rates "do not conform to standards for potable water and I am sure

life will not do well there. These tests indicate that there is acid mine drainage present." But pin-pointing the source of the pollution is difficult -- the Klip could be contaminated by effluent seeping from the mine

and/or from current or former mines in the area. Regardless of the origin of the pollution, Edwin Taolana, a Soweto resident, is concerned about the water's use in traditional medicines. "They say it's red water, that i

a cure. And even ... I used to use it. But then, when I found out about this, I said 'we're killing ourselves' ... We know people that are dying of cancer. People get sick from this ... If the water makes a tin get rust

what will happen to your kidneys?" Despite the presence of mine waste, many residents are unaware of the potential dangers of a degraded environment. "At first I thought it was something that we could be proud of, that

were next to the [mine] dumps. It's like an emblem," said Taolana. "But now I'm worried because this thing is going to affect us ... We've got people who have cows here, and they're drinking the water that comes from th

tailing, and they're irrigating with that water. Directly or indirectly it's affecting us because we buy our vegetables here. "People are clueless that they are sitting on top of a ticking bomb. They don't know it. They

got other things to worry about, like no houses, no jobs, no food, poverty ... To them, it's just a normal thing." When I meet Mosala again he is talking to residents about AMD on the banks of the Klip. He compares thei

apathy with the denial during the early days of the Aids epidemic. "They used to call Aids American ideas used just to discourage sex. But when it started happening to people next door, then they believed you," he said.

s the very same thing with acid mine drainage. There are very few cases where you can actually see the effects of mining. They just won't believe you until they see it." According to Mosala, a lack of education and limit

options fuels a culture of ignorance. "[People] do make comments like 'the dust, the dust', but they usually don't take the next steps, because they don't have the resources ... "Before I was informed about this, I used

e water. I heard about this on the TV and in the paper and I heard about cancer rates and then I became informed and I decided I must -educate people." Given that mining companies and the government share responsibility

the creation and clean-up of mine waste, Mosala said that they must both play a larger role in educating those most affected. "You need to know that if you partake in certain activities it will impact the environment an

your health," said Mosala. "Maybe the government can come to their senses and do something, because people need to be educated ... They should educate people on radio, on TV, put [information] in pamphlets, put it in pl

Zondo state capture commission has reminded us of just how much pressure the Jacob Zuma administration put on the media over the past decade. Mzwanele Manyi's appearance before it simply confirmed that there was nothing

d or clear about the establishment of The New Age newspaper and television news channel ANN7.

But, in the same week, we have seen a media sector preoccupied about the Economic Freedom Fighters. Coverage of its rallies,

conferences and tweets and indignation over the EFF's often inflammatory and bigoted comments have peaked in recent weeks and this week was no different. This is understandable. The EFFs conduct and vitriolic commentary

s been totally unacceptable. READ MORE: Dlamini, Malema ban media from covering their events But the stakes are high and, as the Zondo commission demonstrated this week, the EFF is only one part of the equation.

It is e

to conclude that the rhetoric of the party has got out of hand, that it risks losing the plot now that Zuma is gone. All that may be true, but there is something more at play, a deeper issue that isn't simply about a si

(albeit badly behaved) party.

In many ways, the fetishisation of the EFF is symptomatic of the tendency of elites in South Africa to provide reductive and ahistorical analyses.

Singling out the EFF is seductive. Still

an excessive and singular focus on the EFF is short-sighted and bad for our democracy.

Even well-meaning attempts to address the rambunctious, aggressive, misogynist and increasingly bigoted conduct of the EFF will fal

apart if they target the EFF alone. It may be the loudest threat to media practitioners at the moment, but it is by no means the only or even the most serious. 

The EFF is the news item of the moment and so many outlet

focus on the party as though it exists in a vacuum. This exaggerates the EFF's role and does nothing to help the public to understand the broader issues of media freedom that are at stake.

It also absolves other actors

f responsibility for the current poor state of our democratic discourse. In particular, it lets the ANC off the hook. Over the past 10 years, it is the ruling party whose deliberate actions have most weakened the media a

a whole.

To be sure, in recent months the EFF has been especially badly behaved. From Floyd Shivambu's unacceptably aggressive behaviour towards journalist Adrian de Kock earlier this year to Julius Malema's insistence

n labelling certain members of the media as Stratcom officials in the wake of Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's death and to his more recent violent rhetoric on the sidelines of the Zondo commission, the party has been indefen

Make no mistake, their strategy is designed to scare journalists and prevent scrutiny. It was no accident that, following allegations of wrongdoing in relation to the VBS Mutual Bank scandal, the EFF has been prepared

exploit already existing divides in our society by painting itself as a victim of white monopoly capital.

They have deployed half-truths and bizarre conspiracy theories to defend themselves, growing more bellicose in t

rhetoric as they fight against a media they claim is biased against them. In their version of events, the old apartheid order is alive and well, and it is operating through the media. They are being attacked because the

a doesn't like radical, successful black people.Propaganda mouthpiece: ANN7, like The New Age newspaper, wasn't just a bad news outlet, it was a bad news outlet that was paid for by money funnelled from the public purse.

d Harrison)The trouble with this analysis is that, crudely speaking, it is true or, at least, it contains enough truth to be credible. If you create a category of "media" that doesn't differentiate between outlets as div

as, for example, GroundUp and eNCA, and if you accept that implicit bias works against black people (which, by definition, it does), then they are correct.

But when you get down to specifics, the picture is less clear.

n the absence of any evidence, there is no reason to believe that a journalist who is reporting on the VBS scandal has fabricated allegations because they are anti-black. If the claims are true, the motivations of the jo

although important at a macro level, cannot be used to bat away allegations of wrongdoing.

Still, insufficient attention has been paid to the fact that the EFF's stance on the media in the past few months has been a ca

copy of the ANC's attitude to the media in the past decade. Although there are some (not unimportant) differences in tone, the general idea that a white-controlled media that is deeply invested in black failure is gunni

for the leadership of the ANC has been pervasive within the ANC for some time.

That narrative has only recently begun to change because of the ascendancy of President Cyril Ramaphosa, who has been on a campaign to win

the media as his party heads to the polls.

Dating back to the Thabo Mbeki era, there has been considerable antagonism in the ruling party towards the media. Of course, the sustained viciousness and the development of a

d strategy with which to punish the media kicked in under Zuma. As we saw this past week when Minister of Social Development Bathabile Dlamini banned eNCA from her press conferences, that obtuseness is alive and well in

ruling party.

It is the ANC that created the conditions that the EFF is now exploiting. The ruling party has waged an unrelenting and deeply damaging 10-year campaign against fair and fearless reporting. It was not the

F but the ANC that spent millions of taxpayer rands on and used the pensions of public servants for dubious investments that were aimed at restructuring the media landscape to favour it.

It is the ANC government and ANC

s who worked hand in hand with the Guptas to create proxy ANC mouthpieces, which manufactured news. The New Age and ANN7 made the EFF's rally antics seem like child's play. These weren't just bad news outlets, they were

news outlets that were paid for by money funnelled from the public purse. Their very existence, conjured out of thin air with our resources, were a total insult to taxpayers. 

And let us not forget the SABC, our woeful

c broadcaster. Within that monstrosity of a building in Auckland Park, journalists were subjected to the tyrannical antics of a fool. Promoted by an ANC-rigged board, the mini- dictator Hlaudi Motsoeneng created a vortex

f chaos that continues to swirl to this day.

As if this was not enough, the Twitter streets, which weren't perfect to begin with, were suddenly awash with Bell Pottinger bots. In case we have forgotten, it was Duduzane

who asked Bell Pottinger to run a Twitter bot campaign and instructed them to foster division "along the lines of economic emancipation, whatever".

In other words, part of the blame for the appalling state of social me

discourse today belongs to the Zunami. The EFF army is doing an admirable job catching up, however.

In addition, of course, the ANC also used the media in its factional battles. The Sunday Times debacle is a classic ex

The effect of the onslaught on the media by the ruling party has been profound. Newsrooms have haemorrhaged senior staff. As a result, a generation of young journalists has been led by distracted or politically comprom

managers.

Far too many of today's journalists have cut their teeth in an atmosphere of insecurity and turmoil within their sector. Instead of learning to be independent, tough and fair, they have been taught how to pur

agendas, curry favour and evade accountability.

The cumulative consequences cannot be ignored. Too often audiences are fed half-baked stories that are poorly researched, based on a single source or, worse, only reflect

t people on Twitter think. There simply is not enough rigour in our reporting, in part because of all the pressures I have described above.

There are many wonderful journalists, of course, who work against the odds and

abuse from the public, politicians and their bosses. I will not mention their names here because that might be the kiss of death for them.

Still, there can be no denying that the quality of reporting has declined in th

disastrous decade we are finally leaving behind us. It is clear that the legacy of the ruinous past decade of ANC rule will be with us on the printed page and in public broadcasts for many years to come.

Ultimately, th

theatrics of the EFF and the (understandable but often superficial) responses they trigger among commentators and concerned elites will have a negative effect.

We are heading into a hotly contested election. Lined up a

one another are combative politicians and a weakened and wounded media. This is a toxic combination and those most likely to be poisoned are the voters, who daily grow more and more cynical and less capable of judging f

from fiction.

Perhaps it is time for a mediated process that allows media institutions and politicians to agree on some ground rules. Although there are existing mechanisms, codes and charters, with the election loomin

we need an urgent intervention. READ MORE: Malema hits out at journalists One option to consider is a commission for media institutions and political parties, which would allow parties to air their grievances and confes

to misconduct, such as offering or soliciting bribes and peddling influence.

It could mimic the state capture commission in its form. Whatever was revealed at such a commission would go a long way towards addressing so

of the conspiracy theories that allow both journalists and politicians to hide their agendas and pretend innocence.

A fair election is the outcome of many factors, crucial among them being an electorate that is well in

formed and a media that is capable of disseminating sound and credible information. If our election is to be fair, we need to call for a truce. It's not too late to restore goodwill and respect to our imperfect but hard-won democracy.

Sisonke Msimang is the author of Always Another Country (Jonathan Ball, 2017), and The Resurrection of Winnie Mandela (Jonathan Ball, 2018)
